Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my siblings. “Don’t be late tonight!” my sister wrote, followed by a string of emojis. Mom had been planning this family dinner for weeks, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing and sharing stories like always. But my laptop screen glared back at me, lines of code and error messages taunting me. The project deadline loomed, and the team was waiting on my core module to move forward. Every minute I spent away from my work meant the build stayed stalled, and I could almost feel my manager’s disappointment through the terse emails. My heart pounded as I weighed the warmth of my family’s expectations against the cold urgency of my engineering responsibilities. I wanted to be the reliable sibling, the one who showed up, but I was also the linchpin engineer, the one who couldn’t let the team down. The clock ticked on, and I sat frozen, torn between two worlds that both needed me, unsure which one I would let down tonight.
